awd_titl_txt: CSBR:  Living Stocks --  Transfer of Ownership of Two Large Legacy Collections to the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) has been serving the plant research community since 1991 by collecting, preserving, amplifying and distributing seed and DNA resources of Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis) and related species. These include diverse DNA libraries, full-length cDNA collections, insertion mutant seed populations, seed collections representing global natural variation, as well as genome editing resources. The ABRC's long-term goals are: 1) to continue to enlarge and expand the collection though acquisition of new resources, 2) to store, amplify and distribute new types of resources based on the needs of the community, 3) to increase the efficiency of the operation, to provide higher quality service with a continued low stock price, 4) to provide free access to curated stock information, and 5) to continue to generate, collect and distribute teaching and education outreach kits, to facilitate an integrated plant biology education both locally and nationally.

This award will facilitate the transfer of ownership of two large legacy seed collections, generated through previous NSF funded research. The Center will curate, amplify and distribute novel seed stock collections that have been donated by two retiring or re-orienting Arabidopsis researchers, Dr. David Meinke and Dr. Robert Last. The information from these legacy collections (about 20,000 records) will be integrated within the existing ABRC database infrastructure, in addition to securing, curating and amplifying the physical collections for approximately 6,500 stocks. These collections are larger and more complex to curate and maintain than the stocks normally accepted and this project will support their timely inclusion into the larger ABRC collection. The addition of the Last and Meinke legacy collections also presents an opportunity for the ABRC to highlight these acquisitions through the creation of new education resources and unique, hands-on experiences for K-16 students, educators and the general public. This will include the development of two new Greening the Classroom education modules that include stocks from the legacy collections, and a public hands-on laboratory experience involving "citizen scientists" who will assist in the identification of defective seed from the Last collection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded the transfer of ownership of two large seed collections of Arabidopsis thaliana from the laboratories of Dr. Rob Last and Dr. David Meinke to the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC). The first collection represents the entire Arabidopsis seed stock holdings of the Last Laboratory. This collection was transferred to ABRC because the laboratory’s research program no longer focuses on Arabidopsis. The collection comprised more than 17,000 stocks, not all of which were incorporated into ABRC’s catalog due to redundancy within the collection and between the Last and ABRC collections. The second collection consists of approximately 3,000 carefully curated embryo defective mutant lines representing several decades of work in the Meinke Laboratory.

The data and seed stocks for both collections were received during the first year of funding. The seed stocks of both collections are secured in ABRC’s storage facilities and the process of transferring seeds lines to the Nottingham Arabidopsis Stock Center (NASC), where the collection will be maintained in parallel, and distributed to European researchers is ongoing. Curation for both collections is complete including data integration within the existing ABRC database infrastructure, and incorporation of the seed lines into the ABRC catalog. The lines are available for ordering through the ABRC website and distribution to researchers is ongoing

A total of 17,369 vials of seed were received from the Last Laboratory representing 6,964 unique seed lines. 1,686 of these were selected to be added to the ABRC catalog. Data curation is complete for all lines and 1,628 are currently available for ordering through the ABRC website. Germination tests have been performed on 506 lines and 194 lines have been planted and harvested. A further 11 lines remain on our high priority planting list. Distribution quantities of 447 lines have been sent to NASC and enough seed for reproduction at NASC has been provided for an additional 81 lines. Since the release of the initial batch of stocks from the Last collection in October 2019, there have been 605 requests for stocks from this collection.

ABRC identified 489 new mutant seed lines from the Meinke laboratory to be added to the ABRC catalog. A further 3,073 lines provide additional seed for mutants already in the collection but needing seed increase. Data curation is complete for all lines and 488 of these are currently available for ordering through the ABRC web site. Germination testing has been performed on 223 lines and 20 lines have been planted and harvested. 17 lines remain on our high priority planting list. Distribution quantities of 74 lines have been sent to NASC and enough seed for reproduction at NASC has been provided for an additional 17 lines. Since the release of the Meinke collection in November and December 2019, there have been 69 requests for stocks from this collection.

A citizen science project was developed using seeds from the Last laboratory. This involved providing high quality photographs of the seeds and developing tools to collect phenotyping data from the community. A post candidacy PhD student in STEM Education from the College of Education and Human Ecology was involved in developing an on-line version of the activity which was released on a web-based citizen science platform, Zooniverse, in October 2021. The project was completed in 2022 and additional analysis of seed lines identified through the project allowed us to add phenotypic data for 25 lines where it was not previously recorded.

An REU supplement to the project funded a summer research experience for a recent OSU graduate, who has since enrolled in a Ph.D. graduate program. She participated in PCR based genotyping of T-DNA and transposon insertion mutants of Arabidopsis as well as phenotyping and generation of homozygous seed lines. Remaining funds from the PSC were re-budgeted to allow for a continuation of this work by two undergraduate researchers who were involved in planting, germination testing, and preparing seed lines for distribution. As a result of the REU funding associated with this project 6 new alleles at the GL1 locus have been identified and characterized and 2 new homozygous seed lines have been generated and added to the ABRC collection. An additional 46 lines were analyzed to confirm the GL allele present in the line.

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2024
Modified by: David E Somers
